Plan von dem Scharmützel mit denen rebellen bey James Plantage in der grafschaft Princess Anna in Virginien = [Plan of the skirmish with the rebels at James's Plantation in Princess Anne County in Virginia]
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States - History - Revolution, 1775-1783 - Maps, Manuscript
United States - History - Revolution, 1775-1783 - Campaigns
Princess Anne County (Va.) - Maps, Manuscript
James Plantation (Va.) - Maps, Manuscript
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map showing a skirmish between Hessian and American forces at the James Plantation in Princess Anne County, Virginia during February 1781. (Full caption available at http://library.bloomu.edu/Archives/Maps/maplist.htm ) Published in a 1979 English language translation of the diary of a Hessian officer (Ewald, Johann von. Diary of the American War : a Hessian Journal / translated and edited by Joseph P. Tustin. New Haven : Yale University Press, 1979, p. 283) from a 1791 transcription of notes and sketches found in the original diary (Tagebuch von dem Amerikanischen Kriege). The original map includes the page on which it occurs in the 1791 transcription.
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: United States - Virginia - Princess Anne County ; United States - Viriginia - Princess Anne County - James Plantation

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States - History - Revolution, 1775-1783 - Maps, Manuscript

East Chester (N.Y.) - Maps, Manuscript
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map of the area around East Chester, New York showing Hessian and British plans for an October 3, 1779 ambush of American troops operating in the vicinity. The ambush failed because the Americans approached from an unexpected direction. (Full caption available at http://library.bloomu.edu/Archives/Maps/maplist.htm ) Published in a 1979 English language translation of the diary of a Hessian officer (Ewald, Johann von. Diary of the American War : a Hessian Journal / Translated and edited by Joseph P. Tustin. New Haven : Yale University Press, 1979, p. 181) from a 1791 transcription of notes and sketches found in the original diary (Tagebuch von dem Amerikanischen Kriege). The original map includes the page number on which it occurs in the 1791 transcription.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Catawissa
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Catawissa, Pa. - Maps
Paxton, Joseph, 1786-1861
McKelvy, William
Hughes, George, 1798-1881
Ayer, William, d. 1874
Wampole, John, 1816-1879
Dyer, John
Pealer, Fred
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Survey map showing the location of the different lots of ground belonging to the estate of Col. Joseph Paxton, decd. situate in the town of Cattawissa [sic], and also showing 5 other lots of ground adjoining the town of Cattawissa belonging to the aforesaid estate. The lots within the town plot to said estate shaded dark, with the number of each lot respectively given, and the improvements on each lot designated as follows, houses striped, barns and stable shaded yellow. The blue shade on lot 2 represents the bark house of the old Tan Yards. The 5 Lots adjoining the town are represented in the map in yellow border lines, with the courses and distances respectively given and complement of each lot. Surveyed January A.D. 1862 by Lewis Yetter.
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: United States - Pennsylvania - Catawissa ; United States - Pennsylvania - Columbia County - Franklin Township

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Plan von der Gegend von Montholly = [Plan of the area of Mount Holly]
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States - History - Revolution, 1775-1783 - Maps, Manuscript
United States - History - Revolution, 1775-1783 - Campaigns
Mount Holly (N.J.) - Maps, Manuscript
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map of the area around Mount Holly, New Jersey. The caption (available at http://library.bloomu.edu/Archives/Maps/maplist.htm ) in a 1979 English language translation (Ewald, Johann von. Diary of the American War : a Hessian Journal / translated and edited by Joseph P. Tustin. New Haven : Yale University Press, 1979, p. 28) of the original diary (Tagebuch von dem Amerikanischen Kriege) suggests that the map may have been drawn between December 8 and 26, 1776. However, since the map was published in a 1791 transcription of the original diary prepared from Ewald's notes and sketches, it seems likely it was drawn around that time. The original map includes the page number on which it occurs in the 1791 transcription.
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: United States - New Jersey - Mount Holly

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Plan von der Gegend von Bourdenton, Pourlington bis Monthholly = [Plan of the area of Bordentown, Burlington to Mount Holly]
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States - History - Revolution, 1775-1783 - Maps, Manuscript
United States - History - Revolution, 1775-1783 -Campaigns
Bordentown (N.J.) - Maps, Manuscript
Burlington (N.J.) - Maps
Mount Holly (N.J.) - Maps, Manuscript
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map of the area around Bordentown, Burlington, and Mount Holly, New Jersey. The caption (available at http://library.bloomu.edu/Archives/Maps/maplist.htm ) in a 1979 English language translation (Ewald, Johann von. Diary of the American War : a Hessian Journal / translated and edited by Joseph P. Tustin. New Haven : Yale University Press, 1979, p. 28) of the original diary (Tagebuch von dem Amerikanischen Kreige) suggests that the map may have been drawn berween December 8 and 26, 1776. However, since the map was published in a 1791 transcription of the original diary prepared from Ewald's notes and sketches, it seems likely it was drawn around that time. The original map includes the page number on which it occurs in the 1791 transcription.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Freshman Class Presentation
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
Administration
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: George Meschter, President, Class of 1974 at BSC, presents a check for the recently established Bloomsburg Foundation. Meschter stated, ""The Freshmen Class of 1970 presents this donation of $100 in memory of those students slain at Kent and Jackson State Universities. We shared a common cause with those students and still experience their aspirations for freedom and peace. We desire this sum to be used solely for the purpose of academic scholarships. These scholarships are to be awarded on the basis of academic achievement and financial necessity."" Dr. Nossen responded, ""I hope this will be the beginning of similar type class donations to the Bloomsburg Foundation, particularly funds designed to aid worthy students."" Looking on during the presentation are (from left) George Gruber, treasurer, Dalton; Janet Zagorski, secretary, Plymouth; James Bucci, Reading; and James Neiswender, executive director of the Bloomsburg Foundation, Inc.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Art Gift to College
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
People
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Robert Behr and Edward Horvath, students in the BSC Department of Art, hang two abstract paintings by the contemporary Italian artist, Danilo Bergano, which are a gift to the college from Terrance Hutton, BSC alumnus who is pilot for Pan American Airlines stationed in Berlin, Germany. They will become a part of the growing permanent art collection housed in Bakeless Center for the Humanities

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Big Investors in Agri-Business
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Boyd C. Gartley of the Interstate Milk Producers Cooperative in Philadelphia is shown leading the discussion with the Agri-Business Explorer group of the 1970 summer institute of the Pennsylvania Association of Farm Cooperatives being held this week at Bloomsburg State College. Each student has purchased a $1.00 share of common stock in the cooperative, and will receive his proportional share depending on how well the cooperative does this week before the institute ends

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Exhibit By Art Students During BSC Summer Session
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
Staff
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Exhibit At BSC - An exhibition of paintings and special problems completed by art students during the main summer session at BSC will be on display in the corridor gallery on the third floor of the Bakeless Center for Humanities until September 1. Some of the students shown with their work are (from left) Miss Jean Seglem, Doylestown senior; Dr. Percival R. Roberts, chairman of the art department; Miss Sally Lynch, elementary art teacher from Central Columbia; Mrs. Sally Splain (seated), senior from Almedia; Miss Jan Pios, third grade teacher from Lake Lehman School District; and Mrs. Rosemary McDanel, elementary teacher at Salem Township School, Berwick

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Officers Chosen By Freshmen
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Siegel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Members of the Class of 1968 went to the polls last month and elected officers for this school year. Their term of office will expire in May. The officers are, left to right, Jack Perry, Robert Boose, Sue Harper, Bonnie Yoder, Nelson Ramont, Doug Hippenstiel. Nelson Ramont, class president, is a Liberal Arts major from Scranton. Robert Boose, vice-president, is a Business major from Levittown. Bonnie Yoder, a Business major from Danville, will serve as secretary. Class treasurer is Doug Hippenstiel, an Elementary major from Bloomsburg. Sue Harper, Women's representative, is an Elementary major from Berwyn. Jack Perry, a Secondary major from Dunmore, will serve as men's representative.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: BSC Boosts Ambulance Fund
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Administration
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: William Fedder (left), President of the Bloomsburg Ambulance Association is shown receiving a check for $400 in conjunction with the present funds drive of that organization from Elton Hunsinger, Dean of Students at Bloomsburg State College, who is presenting the sum donated by the Community Government Association which represents the entire college community. The Ambulance Association in return provides free ambulance service for certain athletic events and for BSC students who must be taken to the Bloomsburg Hospital

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: BSC Given Tiffany Glass
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
People
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A handsome panel of Tiffany Glass, a gift of the Bakeless family, has recently been installed in the lower foyer of the Bakeless Center for the Humanities. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Administration
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Representatives of the faculty at Bloomsburg State College are shown at a luncheon meeting in the College with the Board of Trustees following the regular January meeting of the Board. Immediately following the luncheon, the Mid-January commencement exercises were held in Haas Auditorium. Shown are: (left to right) seated - Edgar A. Fenstermacher, trustee; Dr. Louis Thompson, chairman, Academic Affairs Committee; Dr. Wilbert Traebel, vice-president, Faculty Association; E. Guy Bangs, trustee; Frank D. Croop, trustee; standing - Clayton Hinkel, treasurer, Faculty Association; William E. Booth, trustee; Dale Anderson, secretary, Faculty Association; George Turner, president, Faculty Association; Gerald Strauss, representative, Association of Pennsylvania State College and University Faculties (APSCUF); Gerald Beierschmitt, trustee; Dr. John Enman, BSC representative, American Association of University Professors (AAUP); and William A. Lank, president of trustees

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Honor Professor
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
People
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Just prior to the start of the holiday vacation at BSC, members of the advanced shorthand class of Walter S. Rygiel, professor of business education, presented him with a trophy in appreciation of his instruction in typing and shorthand and also in recognition of his influence on the students for good citizenship and clean living. The inscription on the trophy, presented by Richard Keefe, Plymouth, president of the Business Education Club, reads: ""Walter S. Rygiel 'Our Teacher of the Year', presented by Advanced Shorthand Class, 1966, Bloomsburg State College."" Show at the presentation are (from left) Kathleen Eyer, town; Prof. Rygiel; Keefe; and Sandra Bird, Ashland.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Siegel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Jerry Howard now at the end of four years at BSC and a year as president of CGA, believes that change is a password on the BSC campus. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Administration
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Harvey A. Andruss, President, left, and Boyd Buckingham, Director of Development, are shown examining a stone uncovered by workmen placing a new utility line near the site of the former Noetling Hall. Administration
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Prof. Walter S. Rygiel (left) is shown receiving notification of a special resolution of the Bloomsburg State College board of trustees concerning the educator's achievements in directing a shorthand class which won in international competition. The resolution, signed by J. Howard Deily, secretary, commends the recipient for ""his faithful, diligent, efficient and conscientious devotion to duty which has contributed greatly to the high calibre of graduates produced by the Division of Business Education"" and expresses the board's appreciation ""for the outstanding service"" which has been provided.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Early Visitor goes to Bloomsburg Hospital
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Santa Claus, representing the Association of Resident Men at Bloomsburg State College and its ""Toys for Tots"" project, visited the children's ward of Bloomsburg Hospital yesterday morning. Sitting on Santa's lap is Valerie Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Davis, 105 Leonard Street, Bloomsburg; flanking Santa at left is Alison Mowery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Mowery, R.D. 2, Bloomsburg and Richard Conrad, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Conrad, R.D. 2, Benton. Next to Santa is his helper, Dumb Dumb the Clown, play by Pete Shannon, while Mrs. Doris Miller, R. N. looks on. Steve Rosen, in his role of Santa and his helper visited seven area hospitals on Monday and five hospitals and an orphanage yesterday. This year the annual project was under the direction of Joseph Cortese, Assistant Dean of Students, and will conclude with a visit today to the Selinsgrove State School and Hospital at 4:00 p.m.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Appropriate Setting for Teaching
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mrs. Carole Moore, a graduate student from Pottsgrove, is shown telling a Japanese story to a group of Benton area school children in Professor Lynn Watson's graduate class in Children's Literature in the Department of Elementary Education at BSC. Mrs. Moore, who teaches in the Milton area school district at White Deer, is wearing a Japanese kimono along with some of the children, who were delighted with the participation. The two week period of this Children's Literature class covers a different phase each day and has included the Nordic literature, European, Oriental, etc.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mlle. Ghislaine Launay Finds US Land of Strange Concepts
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Siegel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: By sheer coincidence, France is presently represented at BSC. It was through the Bloomsburg Abroad program of study last summer that acquaintance was made with Mademoiselle Ghislaine Launay. Soon after we were established at the University of Dijon, Monsieur Herard, director of the summer course, approached Mrs. Mary Lou John and Mr. Frank Albert, our advisors. Arrangements were made for a dinner engagement with Monsieur Launay, a Dijon rotarian, who customarily entertains foreign visitors to the university.

Students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Students Rehearse 'Hansel and Gretel' - The Children's Theatre class of the BSC Speech Department being conducted during the summer post session, will present the popular ""Hansel and Gretel,"" this Friday morning at nine-thirty at Haas auditorium. The public is invited. There is no admission charge. Course instructor is Ed Morgan, junior from Levittown. From left are Linda Fisher, junior from Montandon, who will play the witch; Mike Shull, junior from Newport, the frog; Steve Frohman and Steve Hummel, fourth grade students, town, who will be children of the forest; Gregg O'Toole, ninth grade student, Bloomsburg, who is Hansel; and Genie Newton, Berwick seventh grade student, who will play Gretel. Other college students in the cast are Denise Garinger, Dallas junior, who will be the good fairy; and Becky Ermish, Nescopeck junior, who will play the mother

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Netherlands Students Watch Pottery Art
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Netherlands Visitors - Nienke Van Leeuween and Meis Saltet, high school students from the Netherlands, are shown with Dr. Robert E. Miller, Chairman of the Committee of International Education at Bloomsburg State College, observing Mrs. Barbara Campbell, Milton, in a ceramics class at BSC. The two visitors are spending seven weeks with Dr. and Mrs. Joseph McCormick, Danville; Nienke is a cousin of Mrs. McCormick. The girls' chief interest while here in the United States is to visit American schools and colleges. In the Netherlands they have completed four years of a five year high school which they call HBS, and are specializing in language including French, German, English, and Dutch. There is also a six year high school in the Netherlands called Gymnasium which has more specialization in physical education

Administration
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Seen here, left to right, Doug Hippenstiel, Dr. Carlough, Mr. Enninful, Judy Gers. George Enninful, the first accredited African correspondent to the UN, discussed the ""Congo Dilemma"" before an assembly of students and faculty on November 9. He traced the history of the Congo, and vicinity, from the time of Livingstone and Stanley to the present. Included in the address was an appraisal of the role played by the UN in the Congo difficulties.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ancient Process of Raku used by Japanese potters
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: There has been a revival in America of raku pottery making, ancient process used by Japanese and Korean potters 400 years ago for creating ceremonial tea bowls. Raymond F. Lewis, visiting assistant professor of art from University of Delaware, introduced the art to ceramics students at BSC this summer along with Indian firing, wheel throwing, hand-building, shaping and glaze compounding. The outdoor demonstration created a lot of interest among students. Taking red hot raku ware from the kiln are (from left) Prof. Lewis; Mrs. Pat Boudman (partly hidden), town, senior art student; David Keefer, Millersburg, junior studio assistant; and Stewart Williams, teacher from Gaithersburg, MD, who are taking the ceramics course

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Teahouse of the August Moon To Be Presented April 22, 23, and 24
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Siegel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bloomsburg Players cast members sometimes get hooked into helping collect props. Pictured here are Henry Fetterman and Howard Kearns. ""The Teahouse of the August Moon"" will be presented by the Bloomsburg Players on April 22, 23, and 24 in Carver Auditorium at 8:15. The play is the third and final production of the Players for the current season. ""Teahouse"" will officially begin the Fourth Spring Arts Festival. Mr. Michael McHale, director, has announced the cast as follows: (in order of appearance) Sakini, Henry Fetterman; Sergeant Gregovich, Albert Roger; Col. Purdy III, Howard Kearns; Captain Fisby, Larry Remley; Old Woman, Martha Siemsen; Old Woman's Daughter, Alberta Harabin; Mr. Hokaida, William Herold; Mr. Omura, James Walter; Mr. Sumata, Terry Moody; Mr. Seiko, Larry Gerber; Miss Higa Jiga, Ann Shepherd; Mr. Keora, James Worth; Mr. Oshira, David Wenner; Lotus Blossom, Barbara Shore; and Captain McLean, Tom Curtis. Mr. Robert Richey is handling the set construction, and Miss Amy Short is acting as business manager for the current production.

Hoch, Dean of Instruction at Bloomsburg State College, is shown extending greetings to Jay Yanoff at the start of two-day institute in Hartline Science Center by the American Institute for Development Education entitled ""Understanding, Evaluating, and Educating Children With Learning Disabilities,"" while Dr. William L. Jones, Director of the Division of Special Education at BSC, and Mrs. Margaret S. Webber, Assistant Professor of Special Education and Dean of the institute, look on. Yanoff, principal speaker for this ten hour lecture institute, is principal and director of an elementary school in Louisville, Ky., and has taught at similar institutes in 13 states throughout the country for college personnel, superintendents, psychologists, and optometrists. Dean Hoch gave the welcoming address to approximately 80 participants from a four state area

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Husky Chess Team Wins Two; Defeats Wilkes and Lehigh Rooks
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Siegel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Athletics
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Gary Deets and opponent deep in thought; The Bloomsburg State College Chess Team defeated the Wilkes College Chess Team on Thursday evening, November 12, by the score of 3 to 2. Dan Marks on the first board for the Husky Rooks employed a Barza opening to defeat Jack Brooks of Wilkes. By use of a French Defense, Gordon Clapp of BSC on second board defeated Mike Hudik in 30 moves. In a game that was even all the way, Gary Deets (Sr., BSC, Northumberland) drew Lehigh's Robert Stetson on first board; Deets played a Caro Kahn Defense.

Administration
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From The Presidents Office - Dr. Harvey A. Andruss, president of Bloomsburg State College, came to Bloomsburg in 1930 to organize and head the Division of Business Education. He was appointed Dean of Instruction in 1937 and began his duties as President in August 1939, when Dr. Francis B. Haas was appointed State Superintendent of Public Instruction. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: New Dance Gyrations Shake Husky; Students Relieve Pent Up Tensions
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Siegel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lately, earth tremors have frequently been charted as originating from the area of the BSC campus. Perhaps it is only coincidental, but they seem to occur every Wednesday, Friday, and Saturday night, centering around either Centennial or Husky Lounge depending upon where the dance is being held that night. The intensity of these tremors is increasing as examinations arrive at nine weeks, and more and more students are releasing more and more tensions through their weird gyrations.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Old North Hall Dormitory Falls; Plan New Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Siegel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Debris is shown falling as workmen begin demolition of Old North Hall to make room for a new dormitory on the Bloomsburg State College campus. North Hall was home to many freshmen men for one or two years. In 1895 the building was first used as an employee dormitory, and by 1905 also contained classroom space before being converted into a men's dorm.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fifteen CGA Committees Performing Legwork For Student Organization
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Siegel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The committee chairs are, first row, left to right: Judy Andrews, Ann Templin, Judi Mann, Donna Schiavo. Second row, l. to r.: Jennifer Smith, Blair Hartman, Frank Milauskas, Gil Gockley, Frank Arlotto, Wally Kahn, Bob White, Charles Swank, Dale Hunsinger, Emma Woodruff. In the past the bourgeois has always come to the fore to make decisions for itself. In the beginning, of course, things are run by those at the top but sooner or later people learn that to get things the way you want them, they must work them out themselves. At BSC, the bourgeois has taken the name of Community Government Association.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A Trip Through Check Point Charlie; Student Speaks With East Berliners
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Siegel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: How would you like to sit down with a priest and a family in East Berlin and question them about their lives in a Communist world? This is what Corey Perron did during his stay in Germany last summer when he participated in the Bloomsburg Student Abroad Program. In an interview, Corey related his experiences while studying, the activities leading up to his solo visit to the Eastern Sector of Berlin, and some of the topics discussed during his meetings with various East Berliners.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: BSC Class Aids Industry
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bloomsburg State College
Students
Staff
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Raymond Eshleman, division manager of Tri-Co. Foods Corp., subsidiary of Hanover Canning Company, spoke to the meteorology class of BSC on the relationship between meteorological elements and heating units in growth of the current pea crop. Members of the class have been supplying Tri-Co Corporation with daily heating unit reports and the amount of daily sunshine which are important elements affecting the pea crop. The college is cooperating with local industry in supplying such information without charge. Shown (left to right) Dr. William B. Sterling, professor of geography; Dr. Wendelin R. Frantz, chairman of the Geography and Earth Science Department; Charles Shupe, a senior in elementary education with an area of concentration in geography; and Raymond Eshleman, division manager of Tri-Co Foods. Shupe is taking a reading with a hand held anemometer of the wind velocity on the roof of the new Hartline Science Center were various meteorology equipment is located. The instrument in the foreground on top of an air vent is a Stokes recorder which is one of a number of new instruments to be installed at the College under the long-term plan of development for the Geography and Earth Science Department under the leadership of President Harvey A. Andruss. The Stokes recorder made in England records the total sunshine for each day on a chart that coincides with the correct sun time each day. These records will be of value to the community of Bloomsburg as well as to the college. Agriculture and industry, as well as prospective residents, are interested in the total of annual sunshine in an area

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of the maypole dance on Merion Green. All the maypoles are being woven as students in white dresses and sashes dance in circles. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Faculty members performing in the "Parade Night" skit as part of the 1967 Faculty Show "Footbook." Tableau based upon Botticelli's Primavera (Florence, Uffizi). Robert Patten (far left with cane), Fritz Janschka as Cupid/ Eros, Carol Carpenter (back shown) as one of 3 Graces, Brunilde S. Ridgway (under Cupid), Mary K. Woodworth, unknown, Charles Mitchell. Others on stage may be: C. Dempsey, J. Yeager, M. A. Calkins, T. Eisenstein. Image used in the Alumnae Bulletin.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Miss Emily Green Balch, Class of 1889, and Katharine E. McBride, President of Bryn Mawr College at the College's 60th Commencement. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Faculty members performing the skit "History of Art 609B: Fellini's 'Beast of the Gods' in the History of Western Thought: An Ontological, Phenomenological and Tautological Approach" as part of the 1979 Faculty Show "Curriculi, Curricula!" oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Inscribed on back: "Citizenship Conference held at Bryn Mawr College. Left to right: President Marion Edwards Park of Bryn Mawr College, and Justice Florence Allen of the Supreme Court of Ohio, only woman Supreme Court Justice in the United States, snapped on the college grounds after they took part in the conference on citizenship held under the auspices of the college, women's clubs of the Main Line and branches of the League of Women Voters. The opening of the college to outsiders is an innovation."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Faculty members performing in the skit "History of Art 609B: Fellini's 'Beast of the Gods' in the History of Western Thought: An Ontological, Phenomenological and Tautological Approach" as part of the 1979 Faculty Show "Curriculi, Curricula!" Pictured: back row (left to right) Gerard Defaux (satyr), Greg Dickerson (Silenus), Neil Forsyth (satyr), Kathleen Slane Wright (nymph), Barbara Lane (nymph), Machteld Mellink (nymph). Front row (Left to Right) Kirsty Dickerson (young Bacchus), Richard Ellis (Mercury), Matthew Yarczower (Jupiter), Dale Kinney (Cybele), Kenneth Strothkamp (Poseidon), Jean Potter (Ceres), Charles Mitchell (Apollo). Backdrop designed by Fritz Janschka. From the James Snyder files.

Bryn Mawr College History
College campuses
Dormitories
Fires
Universities & colleges
Buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Exterior view of the front of Denbigh Hall after the fire of 1902. The photograph is taken from the southwest. Most of the building looks severely damaged by the fire. There is a wheel barrow in front of the building . Ladders are propped against the front walls. Debris can be seen in front of the building. There are several people outside the building. A wooden structural framework can be seen on top of the far left side of the building. The photograph is from the album of Adola Greely.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Costume party photo of a fake family
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bryn Mawr College
Bryn Mawr College History
Students
Universities & colleges
Costumes
Group portraits
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Students in photo are costumed to represent various family members of varying ages and genders. From left to right, the standing "adults" are The Lady from Philadelphia (Clarissa Smith), a woman dressed in fashionable city clothing, Agamemum (Mary D. Hill), a foreign, possibly Asiatic man, Mrs. Peterkin (Florence Butler), a grandmotherly figure, Mr. Peterkin (Mary D. Hopkins), a grandfatherly figure, Solomon John (Pauline Goldmark), a man with a doctor's bag and a fez, and Elizabeth Eliza (Edith Wyatt), a woman in formal dress with a fur muff and a purse. The "little boys" are sitting, their characters unnamed, identities listed as Abigail C. Simon, Elsa Bowman, and Rebecca Wattson. All students pictured members of class of 1896 except Florence Butler, member of class of 1897.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: May Day Celebrations
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bryn Mawr College
Bryn Mawr College History
Universities & colleges
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This page appears to be cut from a scrapbook or photo album. The four images on the page are clipped and pasted from magazines or newspapers. Front, top: students in long draped costumes gather in a group of fifteen or twenty, looking wards three of their fellow actors who are performing a scene from "A Mid-Summer Night's Dream" on the green by a cluster of brambles and trees. Caption reads "Weaver Bottom and His Friends in the Interlude from "A Mid-Summer Night's Dream," Enact Pyramus and Thisbe Making Love Through the Obdurate Wall, with Theseus, Hippolyta and the Athenian Court Enjoying the Spectacle." Front, bottom: an audience of at least one hundred May Day attendees sits in a wide semi-circle on the grass to watch as two actors perform a scene in front of some trees and bushes on a hill. Caption reads "The Greensward, Backed by Fresh-Leafed Shrubbery, and Lighted by the Golden Rays of the Declining Sun, Made the Best of All Stage-Settings for Fairy Plays and Masques Presented to Most Appropriate Audiences of Shepherds, Archers, Clowns, Witches and Ancient Worthies." Back, top: eleven students perform the dance of the milkmaids, costumed in white dresses with dark bodices and striped sleeves, flowered hats, and wooden buckets. Caption reads "The Lord and Ladye of the May Were There, Also Robin hood and His Merry men, and, Prettiest of All the Memorials of Old England, a Chorus of Dainty Milkmaids, Singing and Dancing in Traditional Costumes". Back, bottom: the crowd on Merion Green at the start of the maypole dance. Several figures are mounted on horses. A huge crowd of spectators wraps around the green. Thomas Library visible in the background.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Please cite Bryn Mawr College Special Collections when using this image file. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Faculty members performing in the skit "Curriculum Committee: Café Society" as part of the 1951 Faculty Show "Kind Hearts and Martinets." Backdrop painted by Fritz Janschka. Pictured Joe K. Adams, Richmond Lattimore (3rd from left), Bob Goodale (center) next to Milton Nahm. Lincoln Dryden on right end. Other men listed in skit were Frank S. Parker, Hugues LeBlanc and Alex Soper. Women listed in program were V. Berry, A.L. Broughton, F. deLaguna, M. Esteves, B. Horrax, M. Lehr, M. Northrop, M. Woodworth (far right) and B. Watson. Photograph by Wilbur Boone.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Image from the collection of Rae Millman, student at the Bryn Mawr Summer School for Women Workers in Industry ca. 1925. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bryn Mawr College
Bryn Mawr College History
Universities & colleges
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From May Day, 1900. Approximately twenty students participating in the Robin Hood Play somewhere outdoors. The actors are dressed in elaborate costumes with cloaks, monk's habits, hats, hoods, and bows with quivers of arrows. They are laughing, clustered around a kneeling figure in the center who is held by the arms and restrained by the crowd around her. One other figure in the foreground sits on the grass, cross-legged, about ten feet away.

Bryn Mawr College History
Universities & colleges
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Six students pictured on a path by a hillside on a geology field trip. They wear jeans and blouses with rolled up sleeves. Three have hard hats with headlights affixed; the other three are bareheaded. Two of the students crouch together to consult a folded-out document, possibly a map. One hammers a rock on the ground, while another leans up against a rock face while she hammers. The other two sit against the rock face to consult an unidentified device. A note on the back of the photograph specifies that the geology professor (not pictured) was Dr. Edward H Watson.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Marion Edwards Park, Florence Rena Sabin, Simon Flexner
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: International Newsreel Corp.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bryn Mawr College
Park, Marion Edwards, 1875-1960
Bryn Mawr College History
Universities & colleges
College presidents
Group portraits
Awards
Rites & ceremonies
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Inscribed on back: "Bryn Mawr, PA . . . A feature of the Fiftieth Anniversary Celebration of the founding of Bryn Mawr College November 2nd, was the presentation for the third time of the M. Carey Thomas Award of five thousand dollars to Dr. Florence Rena Sabin, noted Anatomist. The presentation of the award, which given 'At intervals to an American Woman in recognition of eminent achievement', was made by President Marion Edwards Park, who is Chairman of the award committee. The main speaker at the presentation was Dr. Simon Flexner, retired head of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, the organization with which Dr. Sabin has worked for the past ten years. They are shown here at the presentation ceremony--left to right, Dr. Sabin, Marion Edwards Park, and Dr. Flexner."

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bryn Mawr College
Bryn Mawr College History
Universities & colleges
Theatrical productions
Teachers
Photographers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Faculty members performing in the skit "Committee on Aesthetic Regeneration: Pavane pour le petit Prince un peu Mort" as part of the 1955 Faculty Show "The Profs in the Pudding." Dorothy Nepper Marshall stands at center. From left to right, the men pictured are Richard Lattimore, Ernst Berliner, Horace Alwyne, and Joe Berry. Women pictured (order unknown) are Irene Clayton, Elinor Nahm, Jean Oxtoby, and Alice Lattimore probably on the far right. Gift of Marguerite Lehr, October 1984. Photographed by Pruett Studios. (John Pruett of Physics Dept. & wife Esther took all the 1955 photos and sold them to raise money for the new science building.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bryn Mawr College Campus, Aerial View
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bryn Mawr College
College campuses
Bryn Mawr College History
Aerial photographs
Universities & Colleges
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of painting depicting Bryn Mawr College, from an aerial view. Depicts students engaged in a variety of activities, including field hockey, tennis, a book burning for seniors, a parade through the Pembroke Archway in an inset in the upper right corner, May Day celebrations, and seniors singing at seniors' step. Buildings' names and dates of construction are provided. Portraits of M. Carey Thomas; Dr. James E. Rhoads; Marion Edwards Park, first three presidents of the College, at the top. Details of the college's founding found on bottom of page.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Henry Joel Cadbury sitting in the Deanery Garden at Bryn Mawr College
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Cadbury (1883-1974) who graduated from Haverford College (1903) and Harvard College (Ph.D. 1913) taught classics and Biblical Studies at Haverford, Bryn Mawr, and Harvard’s Divinity School for many years before becoming a member of the Board of Directors at Bryn Mawr College, and its Chairman in 1956. Here, the Quaker scholar, lecturer, and social activist sits quietly on the Deanery garden’s well head amidst the bronze putti purchased by M. Carey Thomas – replicas of decorative fountain figures from Herculaneum’s Villa dei Papiri (1st century BCE-79 CE), now housed in the Naples National Archaeological Museum. The Deanery, formerly the residence of Dean, then President M. Carey Thomas, was later used by the Bryn Mawr College Alumnae Association from 1933 until 1968 when the structure, deemed unsafe, was demolished to make way for the construction of Canaday Library. The Deanery garden area which remains, was renamed the Blanca Noel Taft Memorial Garden in 1974.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Please cite Bryn Mawr College Special Collections when using this image file. High-quality scans of materials in the collection are offered for research, publication, and commercial use at the discretion of Bryn Mawr College. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior view of a gym room in the old gymnasium of Bryn Mawr College. Several students stand in line in four rows exercising. The stand with their heels together and toes apart and have both of their hands up to the side. Most of them look straight at the camera. They are wearing dark dresses. Most dresses have class years or positions written on them. Three flags with "1907," "1908," and "1909" written on them hang on the sides of the room. The photograph is from the 1906 yearbook belonging to Grace Wade Levering.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Faculty members performing the skit "History of Art 609B: Fellini's 'Beast of the Gods' in the History of Western Thought: An Ontological, Phenomenological and Tautological Approach" as part of the 1979 Faculty Show "Curriculi, Curricula!" Pictured are: Gerard Defaux, Kirsty Dickerson (young Bacchus), Neil Forsyth (satyr), Matthew Yarczower (Jupiter), Richard Ellis (Mercury), behind him Barbara Lane (nymph) then Dale Kinney (Cybele), Kenneth Strothkamp (Poseidon), Machteld Mellink (nymph), Jean Potter (Ceres) leans toward Charles Mitchell (Apollo), unknown, unknown. Backdrop designed by Fritz Janschke. From James Snyder files.
